title: Get ready for The X Factor... But not as we know it: Celebrity version launches this month
text:
Every judge on a TV talent show is looking for that Susan Boyle moment, the one where the performance on stage is so unexpected that jaws drop to the floor.

Nicole Scherzinger seems to have experienced it with the new series of The X Factor, which is a celebrity version rather than a parade of complete unknowns.

The contestants who captured her attention are rugby players Thom Evans, Ben Foden and Levi Davis, who teamed up in the auditions to form a boy band.

Oiled chests were de rigueur, by all accounts, and it sounds like Nicole gave them full marks. ‘I love the rugby boys,’ she admits during a break in filming today.

‘I love them! Who doesn’t love a bit of rugby boys having a stab at this singing thing? It was like a Magic Mike routine. It got everyone’s attention!’

Nicole reunites with Simon Cowell and Louis Walsh (pictured) for The X Factor Celebrity

Nicole, pictured, revealed the contestants who captured her attention are rugby players Thom Evans, Ben Foden and Levi Davis, who teamed up in the auditions to form a boy band

Other acts have left her swooning too.

The celebrity inclusion that surprised her most was none other than journalist Martin Bashir.

The man who scooped that TV interview with Princess Diana has gone on to establish himself as one of TV’s heavyweight news operators, yet he put himself forward for The X Factor.

Has the world gone mad? Does he get his torso out too?

Alas, all Nicole will confirm is that she was shellshocked to even see him there.

‘He’s the kind of person people are not used to seeing in this light, and the way he spoke about why he did it, his voice, and his performance... well, he was the biggest surprise to me, for sure.’

The idea of a special celeb series was Simon Cowell’s brainchild.

He wanted a tweak to the format that would get everyone talking, and tuning in.

Ever wondered what Strictly Come Dancing’s Brendan Cole and Jeremy Edwards (pictured) from Hollyoaks would sound like together? No, us neither, but they’re doing a duet

The full line-up is eyebrow-raising and includes actors, soap stars and social media influencers. Chat show host Rikki Lake is in there, as is David Hasselhoff’s daughter Hayley and TOWIE’s Megan McKenna.

Actor Kevin McHale is stepping up to the mic (he’s been in Glee, so his singing credentials are a given), so too is Jenny Ryan, better known as one of the Chasers on The Chase. (Can she sing? She certainly can.)

Some acts offer up a celeb double-hit. Ever wondered what Strictly Come Dancing’s Brendan Cole and Jeremy Edwards from Hollyoaks would sound like together?

No, us neither, but they’re doing a duet.

The contestants are stars in their own field, so their careers aren’t depending on it. 'It will be a fun season. But there is proper singing talent there. A couple of people blew me away

There’s a band made up of Love Island stars – contestants Nicole puts in that bracket of ‘the ones you wouldn’t expect to be great, but are’.

It’s the groups – surely the ultimate in manufactured pop – that are interesting, she says.

‘Audiences will know them individually then as a group, so there’s a connection there already.

'But there’s an advantage and a disadvantage, because maybe some of the people aren’t as strong; that might hurt the group.’

Simon knows only too well how putting individual stars together, with a song sheet, can surprise. His big breakthrough was when he, then a lowly record company exec, convinced two actors to team up and bring out a record.

The result was Robson & Jerome – who shifted more records than the established pop stars of the day. Can this be recreated? Well, he hopes so – the prize this year is a recording contract.

The celebrity inclusion that surprised Nicole most was none other than journalist Martin Bashir, pictured. The man who scooped that TV interview with Princess Diana has gone on to establish himself as one of TV’s heavyweight news operators, yet he put himself forward

It’s all quite mad, but when we catch up with Nicole to find out how the early stages of filming have been going, it sounds like the judges are having a blast.

This year sees her return to the panel, along with Simon and another old hand, Louis Walsh. ‘Simon trusts us and knows what he’ll get with us,’ she explains.

She says it’s more relaxed because the judges aren’t sitting there knowing someone’s entire career depends on their call.

‘There’s a little less pressure. They’re stars in their own field, so their careers aren’t depending on it.

I sleep well on a plane, it’s a blessing. My team think I’m crazy, but I’m trying to embrace the madness

'It will be a fun season. But there is proper singing talent there. A couple of people blew me away.’

What a gig to get.

The early auditions were filmed at Simon Cowell’s new £20 million home in Malibu, which is more of a compound than a holiday cottage.

Overlooking the Pacific Ocean, the house has seven bedrooms, staff quarters and a guest suite. Filming took place in the back garden, where there’s a swimming pool, a spa and a koi carp pool.

So has Nicole been lounging about, cocktail in hand? Definitely not.

She sounds more exhausted than anyone in this setting should. It turns out she’s been juggling filming this show with jobs as a judge on Australia’s Got Talent and also the US talent show The Masked Singer, in which celebrities compete in full costume and face masks.

At peak madness, she was flying between LA and Sydney every single day.

Nicole's Instagram is full of pictures of her in Lycra (pictured), doing impossible yoga poses or lifting weights. Those abs, she admits, have not shaped themselves

‘I sleep well on a plane, it’s a blessing. My team think I’m crazy, but I’m trying to embrace the madness.

'Coping with it is about a frame of mind. When you have to land and work, and do two shows back-to-back, there’s no time to complain or think about being tired.’

A conversation with Nicole, 41, doesn’t half make you feel lazy.

She might have been born in Honolulu, Hawaii – surely the most chilled out place – but there’s nothing laidback about her attitude.

I go through phases. Like with the gym, I will go for weeks without working out, but then I’ll say, 'OK, I’d better get back into it.'

‘I go through phases,’ she admits. ‘Like with the gym, I will go for weeks without working out, but then I’ll say, “OK, I’d better get back into it.”

'I fluctuate, like a lot of women, and it’s nice to take a break sometimes. But when you’re wired like me, it’s often the other way.’

Her Instagram is full of pictures of her in Lycra, doing impossible yoga poses or lifting weights. Those abs, she admits, have not shaped themselves.

‘I’m constantly working on myself,’ she says. ‘On my body. If you want a good body you have to work on it, but for me exercise is as much about my mental state too.

'I need it to burn off steam. It’s about frame of mind, maybe even more so than about the physical side.’

Nicole started as a singer herself. She sold 54 million records as part of The Pussycat Dolls, and 16 million as a solo singer.

Andrew Lloyd Weber arranged for her to join the cast of Cats on Broadway after a run in the show in the West End, but things went horribly awry when Nicole pulled out at the last minute, choosing to go with The X Factor. Pictured, Nicole on stage on the West End

Presumably, signing up as a TV judge was partly to do with upping her profile and selling more records? She laughs. ‘I’d love to be able to say that, but with my terrible history I don’t think I’ve ever released a song off the back of these damn shows.’

Yet look at how many of ‘these damn shows’ there have been. She’s appeared on both the US and UK versions of The X Factor as well as Australia’s Got Talent, and she’s clocked up stints as a contestant on Dancing With The Stars (she won, naturally) and I Can Do That, in which the contestants have to master a new skill (yep, she won that too).

This year she will appear on five different shows, across the world. ‘I am doing a lot this year – five shows – but next year I will take a break and focus more on the music. But it’s not as if I sought out all these shows in different countries.

There’ll always be an industry. People still go to see Paul McCartney. I went to see Sade recently, and I love the idea of, in my 60s or 70s, singing with a little jazz band or doing a musical.

'I’m just grateful to be asked. If an opportunity comes along, I will seize it.’

There have been rumours that The Pussycat Dolls are about to reform. No confirmation of that now, but she does admit she misses touring, and the music side of her career. ‘It’s my first love, where my talent truly lies,’ she admits.

‘I put a lot of hard work and heart into whatever I do, but a lot of people can do that. What separates me is the music. I feel as if I’m just beginning with the music.

'There’ll always be an industry. People still go to see Paul McCartney. I went to see Sade recently, and I love the idea of, in my 60s or 70s, singing with a little jazz band or doing a musical.’

She has allied herself with, and been mentored by, two of the biggest names in entertainment.

Do Simon Cowell and Andrew Lloyd Webber, who convinced her into musical theatre in Cats, have much in common personality-wise?

Nicole credits family with helping to keep her calm and grounded. Pictured, with sister Keala

‘They are very different,’ she says. ‘It’s like two parts of the brain. Simon is more business, Andrew is more creative, he’s a master at music.’

He was once her greatest cheerleader. At a time when some dismissed her as a pop singer, Andrew identified her as a future great of musical theatre.

He arranged for her to join the cast of Cats on Broadway after a run in the show in the West End, but things went horribly awry when Nicole pulled out at the last minute, choosing to go with The X Factor.

Andrew was livid, and said so.

‘I’m furious – I really believe she’s the most fantastically talented girl and I went out on a limb to get her for the London Palladium, and it makes me look like an absolute twot with them all,’ he said.

I had a lot of struggles with self-esteem and a lot of insecurities later on that resulted in me having eating disorders because of my body dysmorphia

‘But never mind, there’ll be another girl on Broadway and Nicole will not get her Tony award.’

Ouch! ‘It’s OK. He had every right to feel that way,’ she says today.

‘He fought for me, and I always said I would make it up to him. That relationship means a lot to me because he believed in me from the start, when others didn’t.

'Andrew and his family have been nothing but good to me. It was such a passionate reaction from him, but you can’t knock someone for that.’

But by her own admission, singing is what she’s best at. Was it not a mistake turning down a Broadway role?

‘I don’t think it’s good to have regrets,’ she says. ‘You can’t go back in time. But Andrew and I have rekindled our friendship and I look forward to other projects.’

There’s much chat today of embracing spirituality, not being too hard on herself and ‘learning to be kinder’.

Nicole Sherzinger has judged on previous X factors with Simon Cowell and Louis Walsh. She is pictured here in the 2017 series of the programme

All this is at odds with her schedule, which suggests she’s one of the toughest cookies in showbiz. Her journey through the industry has been turbulent, though.

After she left The Pussycat Dolls she admitted she’d suffered from an eating disorder at the peak of their fame. Insecurities have always haunted her, she admits.

When did it start?

‘I’d always felt that way. I had a lot of struggles with self-esteem and a lot of insecurities later on that resulted in me having eating disorders because of my body dysmorphia.

'I was just really hard on myself growing up and I didn’t like myself very much.

If you want to have a good body you have to work on your body, and if you want a good mental state you have to work on it too. It’s a battle out there

'My 20s were when it was most raging. We had so much success with the Dolls, but I was not as balanced, let’s just say. I’ve had to work on that.’

Was the problem with her, or the industry she was in?

‘Oh, definitely me. You have to take responsibility, although being a part of the industry doesn’t make it any easier. I was hard on myself because I chose to be hard on myself.

'I was a perfectionist, insatiable, nothing ever seemed enough. I was never good enough. But what I’ve learned is that you do have a choice. You have to fight it.’

Is it an ongoing fight, or in the past?

‘Oh, an ongoing fight. I am very spiritual so I like things to be in peace and alignment. The way the world is wired is not spiritual. We have to battle to keep ourselves in peace.’

It doesn’t sound as if she enjoyed her 20s, and she admits she wishes she could have them over again.

The Islanders: Who are they? (L-R) Wes Nelson, Zara McDermott, Eyal Booker and Samira Mighty all appeared on series four of reality dating show Love Island

‘I do. I really do. That’s why I want to be positive now, and seek any positivity because time goes by so fast, and it tries to steal it from you. It’s like a thief in the night, stealing joy, and you don’t want your joy to be stolen.’

I ask if there was a specific moment she found she was happy, and she says, ‘No, I’m still searching. But I don’t know if it’s happiness we should be looking for, it’s more the search for meaning.

'I’m constantly in search of that. Happiness is more of a choice.’ Hard work, though. ‘Yes. If you want to have a good body you have to work on your body, and if you want a good mental state you have to work on it too. It’s a battle out there.’

So how does she keep her mental health in tip-top condition? ‘Counselling, yoga, church, life coaches, psychiatrists, meditation, prayer, running, dancing, family, my nieces... everything.’

You need someone that lifts you up and supports you, someone who understands the ambition

Her personal life is a bit of a closed book. She famously dated Formula 1 champ Lewis Hamilton and more recently Bulgarian tennis ace Grigor Dimitrov, but in August she let slip that she was single on Australia’s Got Talent. So is she?

‘We’re so fortunate to live in a world where women are more encouraged and celebrated for having a career and ambition,’ she says.

‘Of course, that comes with an element of compromise when it comes to your personal life. You need someone that lifts you up and supports you, someone who understands the ambition.

'But that commitment, along with schedules, travel, distance and time, is always something that is going to be challenging, and I’ve had to deal with these difficulties.’

Realistically, she can’t have much time for a private life.

Try Star: Who are they? Three-piece made up of former sportsmen Thom Evans (L) Levi Davis (C) Ben Foden (R). They will compete on The X Factor: Celebrity

She managed to get back home to Hawaii for her birthday this year and spent time with her sister and nieces, which cheered her up. ‘She’s my only sister, the yin to my yang. She’s the better half of me,’ she says of Keala.

She admits her mum (‘the biggest influence in my life’) does want her to settle down and have kids too.

‘All parents do. They just want happiness and family for their children. It is tough for my mum because she sees how hard I work. She wants me to not have to do so much, but she also knows that this is how her daughter is wired.’

Does she want children? ‘I definitely want a family and kids, but I always say, “In God’s timing”. My mum had two children so I guess I always thought I’d have as many as my mum.’

Of course, you don’t have to be married, or even in a relationship, to have kids these days, but she baulks at the idea of going it alone. ‘No, I’m quite traditional.’

She’s also traditional in that she goes to church every week, which will surprise some. ‘I have to. I pray every day. I don’t really know how I would be able to get on if I didn’t believe in a higher power than myself. We are flawed as human beings. My faith is everything that is good about me. It keeps me solid, on purpose.’

Quite what they’d make in her church of the rugby boy band and their oiled torsos is unclear, but since they’ve made her smile, we reckon they’d approve.

The X Factor: Celebrity begins on Saturday 12 October on ITV
description: Nicole Scherzinger discussed returning to British screens for X Factor: Celebrity. Acts include Martin Bashir and a trio of rugby players performing as a band.
